title: Peroneal Neuropathy (Common Peroneal / Common Fibular Neuropathy)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of common peroneal (fibular) neuropathy at the fibular head from initial presentation through electrodiagnostic confirmation, conservative management, and surgical referral. Covers foot drop assessment, localization with EMG/NCS, differentiation from L5 radiculopathy and sciatic neuropathy, ankle-foot orthosis fitting, physical therapy, and indications for surgical decompression or tendon transfer. Settings: ED (acute foot drop evaluation), HOSP (post-surgical/post-traumatic), OPD (primary management). For deep peroneal neuropathy (anterior tarsal tunnel syndrome), refer to specialized evaluation.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Diabetes is the most common metabolic cause of peroneal neuropathy (increased nerve vulnerability)
Screen for diabetes/prediabetes; diabetic nerves more susceptible to compression
Infection screen (post-traumatic); anemia workup; hematologic malignancy
Electrolyte abnormalities; renal function (affects medication dosing)

Extended Workup.rationale: Hypothyroidism increases susceptibility to entrapment neuropathy
Concomitant peripheral neuropathy contributing to nerve vulnerability
Nutritional neuropathy; often deficient with B12
RA-associated peroneal neuropathy (Baker cyst, synovial compression at knee)
Paraproteinemic neuropathy; myeloma with focal nerve involvement
Gout with tophi at fibular head (rare but reported cause)

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Multifocal motor neuropathy with conduction block mimicking peroneal neuropathy
Vasculitic neuropathy associated with hepatitis (PAN, cryoglobulinemia)
Hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies (HNPP) if recurrent or bilateral

Essential/First-line.timing: Gold standard for diagnosis and localization; optimal timing 2-3 weeks post-onset for denervation; NCS abnormalities may be immediate
Essential/First-line.target: Focal slowing or conduction block at fibular head; reduced CMAP amplitude peroneal nerve; normal superficial peroneal SNAP if at fibular head; denervation in tibialis anterior, peroneus longus, extensor digitorum brevis

Essential/First-line.timing: Exclude fracture of proximal fibula, osteophytes, or bony mass at fibular head
Essential/First-line.target: Normal; no fracture or mass at fibular head

Extended.timing: Evaluate for mass lesion (ganglion cyst, nerve sheath tumor, Baker cyst) compressing peroneal nerve at fibular head
Extended.target: No mass lesion; normal peroneal nerve signal

Extended.item: MRI knee with and without contrast (CPT 73723)
Extended.timing: If tumor or intraneural pathology suspected; post-gadolinium enhancement in nerve sheath tumor

Extended.item: Ultrasound of peroneal nerve at fibular head (CPT 76882)
Extended.timing: Point-of-care evaluation; can visualize nerve swelling, ganglion cyst, entrapment; operator-dependent
Extended.target: Normal nerve caliber at fibular head (<5 mm CSA typical); no cyst or mass

Extended.timing: Rule out L5 radiculopathy if clinical localization uncertain
Extended.target: No L4-L5 or L5-S1 foraminal stenosis/disc herniation

Extended.item: MRI lumbar spine with and without contrast (CPT 72158)
Extended.timing: If neoplastic or inflammatory radiculopathy suspected

Rare/Specialized.timing: High-resolution nerve imaging if standard MRI inconclusive; can visualize nerve fascicular detail
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal nerve signal and caliber; no intraneural or perineural pathology

Rare/Specialized.timing: Bony pathology at fibular head not visualized on X-ray

Rare/Specialized.item: Diagnostic nerve block (peroneal at fibular head) (CPT 64450)
Rare/Specialized.timing: Confirm localization if clinical and electrodiagnostic data discordant
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Infection; anticoagulation; allergy to local anesthetic

Rare/Specialized.timing: Exclude sciatic nerve lesion or pelvic mass causing proximal nerve injury
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal sciatic nerve; no pelvic mass

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line for foot drop regardless of etiology; prevents tripping, ankle sprains, and gait instability

doseOptions.orderSentence: Ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) Custom or prefabricated AFO External

dosing.instructions: Fit AFO immediately when foot drop identified; custom molded if expected >6 months; prefabricated for acute/temporary use; dorsiflexion assist type preferred
dosing.orderSentence: Ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) Custom or prefabricated AFO External

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Skin breakdown at calf/ankle; fit adjustment; compliance

Acute/Emergent.indication: Eliminate identified external compression at fibular head

dosing.instructions: Stop leg crossing; remove tight casts, stockings, or braces; pad fibular head if bedbound; modify positioning

Acute/Emergent.indication: Proximal fibula fracture associated with peroneal nerve injury

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg qHS; increase by 10 mg weekly; max 75 mg qHS

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Cardiac conduction abnormality; urinary retention; glaucoma; elderly

dosing.instructions: Ibuprofen 400 mg TID with food; short course 7-14 days; not for chronic neuropathic pain

Rehabilitative/Conservative.indication: Core rehabilitation for foot drop; nerve recovery optimization; gait training

dosing.instructions: Ankle dorsiflexion/eversion strengthening; gait training with AFO; balance exercises; nerve gliding; electrical stimulation (NMES) to tibialis anterior

Rehabilitative/Conservative.monitoring: Muscle strength grading (MRC scale); gait quality; functional improvement

Rehabilitative/Conservative.indication: Prevent muscle atrophy during reinnervation; maintain ankle dorsiflexor mass

dosing.instructions: Apply to tibialis anterior; 20-30 minutes daily; per PT protocol; during period of denervation/reinnervation
dosing.orderSentence: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) NMES device External

Rehabilitative/Conservative.contraindications: Pacemaker/defibrillator; over open wound; deep vein thrombosis
Rehabilitative/Conservative.monitoring: Muscle bulk; contraction quality; skin irritation

Rehabilitative/Conservative.indication: Prevent further compression in hospitalized or bedbound patients

doseOptions.orderSentence: Fibular head padding/protection Foam pad External

dosing.instructions: Place foam pad at lateral knee/fibular head; avoid leg crossing; reposition every 2 hours
dosing.orderSentence: Fibular head padding/protection Foam pad External

Surgical Treatment.item: Peroneal nerve decompression at fibular head (CPT 64708)
Surgical Treatment.indication: Entrapment neuropathy with identifiable compression (fibrous band, tight peroneal tunnel); failed conservative management 3-6 months; progressive weakness

doseOptions.orderSentence: Peroneal nerve decompression at fibular head (CPT 64708) Surgical decompression Outpatient surgery

dosing.instructions: Release of peroneal tunnel (fascial arch of peroneus longus); neurolysis of common peroneal nerve at fibular head; typically outpatient
dosing.orderSentence: Peroneal nerve decompression at fibular head (CPT 64708) Surgical decompression Outpatient surgery

Surgical Treatment.contraindications: Active infection; severe medical comorbidity; complete nerve transection (requires repair instead)
Surgical Treatment.monitoring: Post-op motor/sensory exam; wound healing; EMG at 3-6 months post-op

Surgical Treatment.indication: Complete nerve transection from trauma (laceration, fracture); no recovery on serial EMG at 3-6 months with absent motor units on voluntary activation

doseOptions.orderSentence: Peroneal nerve repair/grafting (CPT 64712) Nerve repair or cable graft Inpatient surgery

dosing.instructions: Direct repair if gap <2 cm; sural nerve cable graft if gap >2 cm; timing optimal within 6 months of injury
dosing.orderSentence: Peroneal nerve repair/grafting (CPT 64712) Nerve repair or cable graft Inpatient surgery

Surgical Treatment.contraindications: Severe medical comorbidity; poor surgical candidate; gap too large for grafting (>6-8 cm)
Surgical Treatment.monitoring: Serial EMG q3 months; motor function; reinnervation signs

Surgical Treatment.indication: Irreversible foot drop; no EMG evidence of reinnervation at 12-18 months; functional deficit despite AFO

doseOptions.orderSentence: Posterior tibial tendon transfer (CPT 27690) Tendon transfer Inpatient surgery

dosing.instructions: Transfer of posterior tibialis tendon to dorsum of foot to restore dorsiflexion; requires intact posterior tibial nerve
dosing.orderSentence: Posterior tibial tendon transfer (CPT 27690) Tendon transfer Inpatient surgery

Surgical Treatment.contraindications: Active infection; non-ambulatory patient; insufficient posterior tibial muscle
Surgical Treatment.monitoring: Post-op immobilization 6-8 weeks; PT for retraining; gait analysis

Surgical Treatment.indication: Ganglion cyst at fibular head compressing peroneal nerve; identified on MRI or ultrasound

doseOptions.orderSentence: Ganglion cyst excision (CPT 27347) Surgical excision Outpatient surgery

dosing.instructions: Excise cyst with capsular base; decompress nerve simultaneously
dosing.orderSentence: Ganglion cyst excision (CPT 27347) Surgical excision Outpatient surgery

Referrals & Consults.item: Electrodiagnostic medicine/neurology for NCS/EMG to confirm diagnosis, localize lesion, and assess severity; optimal timing 2-3 weeks post-onset
Orthopedic surgery or peripheral nerve surgery referral if mass lesion, fracture, or failed conservative management >3-6 months
Physical medicine and rehabilitation (PM&R) for comprehensive foot drop rehabilitation program and AFO fitting
Physical therapy for gait training, ankle strengthening, balance exercises, and NMES program
Orthotics/prosthetics for custom AFO fitting if foot drop expected to persist >6 months
Neurosurgery consultation if sciatic nerve or proximal lesion suspected on imaging
Endocrinology for diabetes optimization if contributing to nerve vulnerability
Podiatry if secondary foot deformity developing (equinovarus contracture)
Occupational medicine for workplace modification if occupational factors contributed to compression
Genetics referral if HNPP suspected (recurrent pressure palsies, family history)

Patient Instructions.item: Wear ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) during all walking to prevent tripping and ankle injury; remove only for bathing and sleeping
Do not cross legs while sitting as this compresses the peroneal nerve at the fibular head and worsens injury
Avoid prolonged squatting, kneeling, or positions that put pressure on the outer knee area
Perform ankle dorsiflexion and eversion exercises as instructed by physical therapist to maintain muscle strength during recovery
Check lateral leg and foot daily for skin breakdown, especially if sensation is reduced; report any sores or ulcers
Report worsening weakness (new difficulty lifting toes), spreading numbness, or pain to physician as this indicates progression requiring urgent re-evaluation
Nerve recovery is slow (approximately 1 inch per month); improvement takes 6-12 months; maintain therapy and AFO use during this period
Avoid tight boots, stockings, or knee braces that compress the area below the outer knee
Use caution on stairs and uneven surfaces; the AFO helps but does not fully replace normal ankle function
If diabetic, maintain strict blood sugar control as elevated glucose impairs nerve recovery
Pad the lateral knee area when sleeping on the side; place a pillow between the legs

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Lose weight if overweight/obese; excess weight increases pressure on peripheral nerves and slows recovery
Avoid habitual leg crossing; this is the most common compressive cause of peroneal neuropathy ("crossed-leg palsy")
Optimize glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) as diabetes impairs nerve recovery and increases vulnerability to compression
Stop smoking to improve microvascular circulation and nerve healing
Maintain adequate nutrition including B vitamins, protein, and micronutrients for nerve repair
Wear appropriate footwear: avoid high-top boots or tight lace-up shoes that compress the dorsal foot (deep peroneal branch)
For hospitalized patients: apply fibular head padding, reposition frequently, and avoid external compression to prevent iatrogenic peroneal neuropathy
Implement fall prevention measures at home: remove loose rugs, ensure adequate lighting, install grab bars if balance impaired
Notify surgical team of peroneal neuropathy risk during any planned lower extremity surgery, especially knee replacement or proximal fibula procedures

differential.features: Back pain radiating to leg; weakness includes hip abduction (gluteus medius) and toe extension; inversion weakness (tibialis posterior - L5 innervated but tibial nerve); positive straight leg raise; reflex usually normal (no L5 reflex); sensory loss extends to medial foot
differential.tests: MRI lumbar spine (L4-L5 disc, foraminal stenosis); EMG shows denervation in L5 myotome including non-peroneal muscles (tibialis posterior, gluteus medius); normal peroneal NCS across fibular head

differential.features: Weakness involves both peroneal AND tibial nerve distributions (plantar flexion weakness); hamstring weakness possible; hip/buttock pain; history of hip surgery, injection, or trauma
differential.tests: EMG shows denervation in tibial-innervated muscles (gastrocnemius, tibialis posterior); abnormal tibial NCS; short head biceps femoris (peroneal division) vs long head (tibial division) helps localize within sciatic

differential.features: Involves multiple nerve distributions (femoral + peroneal + tibial); hip flexion and knee extension weakness possible; pelvic pain; diabetes, malignancy, or radiation history
differential.tests: EMG shows denervation across L2-S1 myotome; MRI pelvis/plexus; CT abdomen/pelvis for mass

differential.diagnosis: Hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies (HNPP)
differential.features: Recurrent, episodic pressure palsies at multiple sites; family history; young onset; disproportionate slowing on NCS at compression sites
differential.tests: Genetic testing for PMP22 deletion; NCS shows diffuse conduction slowing at entrapment sites; nerve biopsy shows tomaculous neuropathy

differential.features: Progressive weakness without sensory loss; fasciculations; upper motor neuron signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski); bulbar symptoms in advanced disease
differential.tests: EMG shows widespread denervation/reinnervation in 3+ regions; normal sensory NCS; no conduction block at fibular head

differential.diagnosis: Multifocal motor neuropathy with conduction block (MMN)
differential.features: Asymmetric distal weakness (often upper limb first); no sensory loss; conduction block outside typical entrapment sites; may mimic peroneal neuropathy
differential.tests: Anti-GM1 antibodies; NCS shows motor conduction block in non-entrapment sites; normal sensory studies

differential.features: Weakness limited to EDB; sensory loss confined to first web space; foot dorsiflexion preserved; compression at ankle (tight shoes, trauma)
differential.tests: EMG/NCS localizes to ankle; fibular head conduction normal; selective EDB denervation only

differential.features: Acute onset with trauma; severe pain, tense compartment; pain with passive stretch of toes; late finding: foot drop
differential.tests: Compartment pressure measurement (>30 mmHg or within 30 mmHg of diastolic); clinical diagnosis; surgical emergency

differential.features: Stepwise involvement of multiple nerves; systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss, rash); painful
differential.tests: ESR, CRP, ANCA, hepatitis panel; nerve biopsy shows vasculitis; multifocal EMG abnormalities

differential.features: Sensory loss over lateral leg and dorsal foot; no motor weakness (unless proximal injury); lateral leg pain; injury at mid-leg fascial defect
differential.tests: EMG/NCS: abnormal superficial peroneal SNAP; normal deep peroneal motor; normal tibialis anterior on EMG

differential.features: Inconsistent weakness on formal testing; give-way weakness; Hoover sign positive; no EMG abnormalities; foot dragged but toe clears ground on distraction
differential.tests: Normal NCS/EMG; inconsistent exam; psychiatric comorbidity; symptom onset with psychosocial stressor

differential.features: Progressive foot drop; palpable fullness at fibular head; ascending weakness pattern follows articular branch from superior tibiofibular joint
differential.tests: MRI shows intraneural cyst with tubular extension along articular branch; ultrasound shows cystic structure within nerve

differential.features: Acute traumatic onset; significant knee instability; vascular injury risk (popliteal artery); high-energy mechanism
differential.tests: X-ray/CT shows fracture or dislocation; vascular assessment (ABI, CTA); NCS after acute phase

evidence.recommendation: Common peroneal neuropathy is the most common mononeuropathy of the lower extremity; fibular head is the most frequent compression site
EMG/NCS is the gold standard for diagnosis and localization of peroneal neuropathy; conduction block at fibular head distinguishes demyelinating from axonal lesion
Habitual leg crossing is the most common identifiable cause of peroneal neuropathy at the fibular head
Weight loss >10 kg is a significant risk factor for peroneal neuropathy (loss of protective fat pad at fibular head)
Diabetes mellitus increases susceptibility to focal compression neuropathies including peroneal nerve
evidence.source: [Pourmemari MH et al. Acta Neurol Scand 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29488200/)

evidence.recommendation: AFO use improves gait mechanics and reduces fall risk in patients with foot drop
evidence.source: [Alam M et al. Prosthet Orthot Int 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24327668/)

evidence.recommendation: Surgical decompression of peroneal nerve at fibular head shows good outcomes in selected entrapment cases
evidence.source: [Mont MA et al. Clin Orthop Relat Res 1996](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8769449/)

evidence.recommendation: Peroneal intraneural ganglion cysts originate from the superior tibiofibular joint via the articular branch; surgical disconnection of articular branch prevents recurrence
Posterior tibial tendon transfer provides durable functional improvement in irreversible foot drop
evidence.source: [Vigasio A et al. J Bone Joint Surg Am 2008](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18519322/)

evidence.recommendation: MRI and ultrasound are complementary for evaluating structural causes of peroneal neuropathy
HNPP (PMP22 deletion) should be suspected in recurrent or bilateral peroneal neuropathy, especially with family history
Neuromuscular electrical stimulation helps maintain muscle bulk during denervation period but evidence is limited
evidence.source: [Kern H et al. Eur J Transl Myol 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26913147/)

evidence.recommendation: Short head of biceps femoris EMG helps differentiate peroneal neuropathy at fibular head from sciatic neuropathy (peroneal division)
AANEM practice parameter: electrodiagnostic evaluation of patients with suspected peroneal neuropathy at the knee

monitoring.action: If no improvement at 3 months, repeat EMG; if worsening, expedite surgical referral
Eversion loss suggests superficial peroneal involvement; reassess localization
If isolated loss, evaluate for deep peroneal branch lesion
Expanding sensory loss suggests progression or alternative diagnosis
Adjust AFO; modify PT program; assess surgical candidacy if no improvement

monitoring.frequency: 3-6 months post-onset; then q6 months if not recovering
monitoring.action: If no reinnervation at 6 months, pursue surgical exploration; if reinnervation present, continue conservative management
Refit if needed; address compliance barriers
Intensify diabetes management for nerve recovery optimization
Initiate wound care; adjust AFO/padding; podiatry referral
Modify PT program; home safety evaluation; add assistive device

monitoring.frequency: 2 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months post-op
monitoring.action: If no improvement by 6 months post-decompression, repeat EMG and evaluate for revision or tendon transfer

disposition.criteria: Foot drop identified; AFO fitted; able to ambulate safely with AFO; outpatient neurology/EMG follow-up arranged; no progressive deficit; no compartment syndrome

Acute traumatic peroneal nerve injury requiring surgical evaluation; post-knee surgery with new foot drop; compartment syndrome requiring fasciotomy; progressive mononeuropathy multiplex requiring inpatient workup
Compartment syndrome with vascular compromise; polytrauma with peroneal nerve injury; not typical for isolated peroneal neuropathy

Suspected compartment syndrome; mass lesion causing acute progressive nerve compression; complete nerve transection from open injury; rapidly progressive foot drop with no identifiable compressive cause
Failed conservative therapy at 3-6 months; ganglion cyst or mass at fibular head; no EMG evidence of reinnervation at 6 months; chronic complete foot drop for tendon transfer evaluation
Most patients; initial evaluation with EMG at 2-3 weeks; repeat EMG at 3-6 months; PT prescription; AFO fitting; reassess at 4-6 week intervals
